title: Body language experts reveal how they knew child-killer Mick Philpott was lying about his guilt
text:

Experts have revealed how they knew lying child-killer Mick Philpott was guilty - a year before he was convicted of causing his six kids' deaths by torching their family home. 
"Shameless Mick" betrayed telltale signs of deceit as he dramatically broke down at a press appeal over the inferno, according to professors in linguistics and body languages. 
Philpott was jailed for life after being found guilty of six counts of manslaughter in 2013, while his wife Mairead and family friend Paul Mosley were each jailed for 17 years for their parts in the conspiracy. 
The six Philpott children - Duwayne, 13, his sister, Jade, 10, and their brothers, John, nine, Jack, eight, Jesse, six and Jayden, five - all died from the effects of smoke inhalation after flames swept through their home in Derby in 2012. Mick and Mairead Philpott dramatically broke down at a press conference after their children's death (Photo: PA / Channel 5) 
The couple wept at an extraordinary press conference as they appealed for witnesses to the fire in the following days. 
It was then that experts spotted clues that pointed to their guilt, a TV documentary reveals tonight. 
In two-part series 'Faking It: Tears of a Crime', experts in body language, linguistics and psychology offer their insights into criminal behaviour by analysing the words and actions of four high-profile criminals and reveal the telltale signs. Read More Moment Ann Widdecombe thought child-killer Mick Philpott was going to attack her after she called him 'coward' Experts say the couple's crocodile tears gave away their guilt (Photo: PA / Channel 5) 
Professor Dawn Archer, a specialist in linguistics at Manchester Metropolitan University, told the Derby Telegraph : "We have to remember this was a public appeal which was understood to be taking place to try help find those responsible for the fire which killed six children and we would look to see if he behaves like we would expect. 
"There are many channels of communication and we would look at a person's body language and facial expression and see if they are saying something different to the words they use. 
"In the press conference, Philpott holds his sad expression and emotion too long and his sobs appear fake." The body language of Mick Philpott and wife Mairead betrayed their guilt, say professors who analysed footage (Photo: PA) Mick Philpott was found guilty of the manslaughter of his six children 
She added: "In most people, emotion comes and goes and, when someone says something positive, like when he said something good is going to come out of this in the case of the family donating Dwayne's organs, he holds the sad expression. 
"Often, a person who is sad will drop their shoulders and hold themselves different and this will make their voice low â€“ but, in Philpott's case, he continues to be loud and vocal. Mairead is the same with her eyebrows held in a triangle shape looking sad throughout the whole conference, unless she puts her face to the table. 
"Also, the only child he mentions by name is Dwayne and that is when he is talking about donating his organs, no other child is named but he does name neighbours who helped. This suggests psychological distancing and Philpott could be doing this because he is sad but also he could be doing it because he is guilty." The fire-scorched window of the house following the blaze in 2012 (Photo: Getty Images) The front room (Photo: CPS) 
Prof. Archer features in the programme as The Listener - a specialist in linguistics who can detect manipulation. 
The other experts are known as The Watcher, who reads micro-facial expressions and body language and can detect deception, and The Profiler, a psychologist who explains inexplicable human behaviour. 
A spokeswoman for the programme said: "Unknowingly criminals offer clues to guilt and the experts decode the clues in the series. 
"For example, the face has 43 muscles and is capable of 10,000 different expressions and if you learn to read the muscle movements and these conflict with the story the person is telling, you know they are lying. 
"The muscles can't be suppressed and you can tell when someone is faking sadness. The pitch of the voice and the language they use/ or didn't use can also give the game away and be used to separate fact from fiction." Read More 
The Philpotts conspired to burn down their home to frame Lisa Willis, Mick Philpott's live-in mistress, after she left the family home with her four children a few months before the fire. 
A custody hearing over the children was scheduled to take place on the morning of the fire. 
Philpott hatched a plan with wife Mairead and Mosley to incriminate Willis while posing as a hero who saved his children. Floral tributes adorn the pavement outside a house, later demolished, in which the Philpott children died (Photo: Getty) 
The fire was started after petrol was poured through a letterbox, but the planned rescue went tragically wrong when he was beaten back the flames as the blaze got out of control in seconds and the children perished. 
Kerry Daynes, a forensic psychologist who appears on the programme, concluded of Philpott: "He's manipulative, reckless, highly narcissistic, and arrogant." 
The documentary will also hear how Ann Widdecombe thought lying Philpott was about to attack her after she branded him a "coward". 
The former Tory minster recalled "Shameless Mick" angrily squaring up to her in 2007. 
'Faking It: Tears of a Crime' airs on Investigation Discovery on Friday, January 6 and Friday, January 13 at 10pm. Like us on Facebook
